Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: An anthropological exploration of the efficacy of conditional cash transfers (CCTs) on food security

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Indiana University PhD candidate, Ana De Lima, supervised by Prof. Eduardo Brondízio, will investigate the impact of condition cash transfer (CCT) programs on the nutrition of children's diets. The research will focus the study on the Brazilian government's family cash transfer program, the Bolsa Família (BFP), which is an excellent baseline for analyzing CCTs as it has been widely assessed since its inception in 2003 and consumption of processed foods in the rural areas it serves has been on the rise. In particular, the study will look at associations between management of the benefit by mothers in households with different food provisioning strategies and children's food intake. In addition to documenting the management of funds, they will investigate how the mothers' understanding of what represents a good diet influences children's nutrition. This research will use an integrative methodological approach that includes participant observation during grocery shopping, household surveys using structured interviews, inventories of house pantries, food production and procurement for consumption, dietary recalls, anthropometry, and isotope analysis of fingernail fragments (to elucidate dietary history). The researchers will undertake 12 months of fieldwork.

Many evaluations of CCTs such as the BFP and the impact on child nutrition have yielded inconsistent results. This is likely because of their largely quantitative, short-term foci. This research builds upon previous research in economic and nutritional anthropology, adding the BFP as an object of inquiry. This research will develop and test an empirical conceptual model and methodology to elucidate linkages among cash transfer policies, household economic and dietary decision, and child nutrition.

This research will help us better understand how effective CCT programs are not only in areas such as Amazonas where the research will take place, but globally as such programs are implemented to other countries and continents. The results will also contribute to a better understanding of social assistance programs in the U.S. Food security, particularly as it affects children, has been a top initiative of the U.S. government in recent years. Understanding how cash assistance programs contribute to nutritious diets and in other cases obesity will lead to a healthier population. It has been argued that poor nutrition among poor families is a contributing factor to perpetuating poverty.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Bolsa Familia Program (BFP) is a conditional cash transfer (CCT) scheme that has reached almost a quarter of the Brazilian population. The program targets households in extreme poverty through direct cash transfers from the federal government. Essentially, debit cards are issued, preferably to mothers in a household, and monthly cash transfers are made on the condition that their children meet education (minimum school attendance) and health requirements (vaccinations). The program operates under the assumption that mothers make use of the cash benefit in support of their children’s health.

The research conducted by Ana Carolina de Lima (co-PI), supervised by Dr. Eduardo Brondizio (PI), is an in-depth investigation of the impacts of the BFP on the health status of children living in the Brazilian Amazon. In the study area chronic child malnutrition has been widely assessed, as has the rise in consumption of processed foods. Whereas previous evaluations of the BFP concerning its impact on child nutrition used predominantly country-level survey data yielded inconsistent results, this research aims at understanding how the program works on the ground.

Bringing an anthropological approach to the issue, de Lima spent over a year living in communities located in the rural Amazon. The goal was to understand the dynamics of the BFP cash benefit management in the household, the food culture, diets, and ultimately the consequences to children’s health. This research is unprecedented as it integrates a complex set of methodologies to contextualize and effectively examine two worldwide trends: CCTs and the rise in processed food consumption. CCT policies have spread throughout Latin America, and are now making their way into developed countries; child obesity has been a growing concern in urban and rural areas of developing countries for some time.

To address the research goals, de Lima conducted community census surveys, interviewed mothers about BFP cash benefit management, and elicited ideas about good diets from mothers and children. She also collected dietary (24-hour dietary recalls, fingernail fragments for stable isotope analysis, food pantry inventories) and anthropometric (height, weight, skinfolds, and waist circumference) data with mothers and children (three times during the year, to account for fluctuations previously described in the literature). Also, an activity of ranking pictures of foods was carried out in order to evaluate ideas of a good diet (cultural consensus analysis).

In parallel, de Lima conducted participant observation, accompanying mothers and children when they procured foods within and around the community, and on trips to the nearest town. Moreover, she facilitated photovoice meetings with children (photographs and narratives produced by participants about their routines), culminating in exhibits organized locally and in the USA (Denver Art Museum during the Latino Festival in November of 2015 and currently at Indiana University’s Department of Anthropology).

During her fieldwork, de Lima also worked closely with a graduate student from a local university, and collaborated as an assistant instructor in three short courses at regional universities. Most data collection was conducted in 2014, but de Lima returned to the field at the end of 2015 to present preliminary results to participants and to monitor ongoing data collection (height and weight records by health agents and photovoice with children). During that period, de Lima collected data on intestinal parasitic infections to assist in interpreting results from previous health status data (dietary and anthropometric variables). A local volunteer physician visited the communities providing medication to participants based on the results of fecal sample analysis.

De Lima completed all data collection and analysis planned for this project, and is finalizing the last chapter of her dissertation. Her doctoral defense is scheduled for February of 2017, and she will subsequently work on publishing in academic journals of high impact. The five chapters of her dissertation address: i) the historical and socio-cultural context of the communities studied, bringing children’s accounts to the forefront of the analysis; ii) environmental variables, fluctuations in diets, and associations with children’s health (including the occurrence of parasitic infections); iii) household BFP cash-benefit management and money expenditure; iv) BFP participation and its associations with consumption of processed foods and food production; v) associations between household cash-benefit management and children’s health status, including gender differences.

Results from this research have practical implications for local, national, and global institutions interested in promoting children’s health, tackling both malnutrition and obesity. In addition, with the recent spread of CCT policies, this research sets the basis for studying consequences to children’s health not restricted to the Amazon, but also providing insights in foreseeing effects of CCTs in other contexts. The BFP is frequently featured in the Brazilian national news, at times for its perceived accomplishments, as well as for its weaknesses. Publication of findings from this research will likely trigger media attention, as well as provide instrumental information to policymakers.
